intro: Siphocampylus rusbyanus, commonly known as the Rusby's siphocampylus, is a rare flowering plant native to specific regions of the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its slender, branching stems and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in arid or semi-arid environments. Its foliage consists of finely divided leaves, and it produces white or pale yellow flowers that bloom in late spring or early summer. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species in its native range.
